Ben Maurer wrote:

> Code like:
> 
> try {
>      // ...
> } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
>      System.out.println ("1");
> } catch (Exception e) {
>      System.out.println ("2");
> }
> 
> Will change output if you change from throwing an Exception to an
> IllegalArgumentException. In JUnit we have assertEquals, not
> assertKindaLike. Assertions should be *exact* specifications of
> behavior.

What test that /was/ passing then failed (or was failing, then passed) 
because of the subclass check? I understand that a different handler was 
being used, but to change from an unchecked exception to a checked 
exception seems to me to be a surprising and weird change without also 
wanting to change the exception handlers.

At any rate, none of that addresses your original point. How do you 
write a test that shows that the second handler is being hit when it 
should? Do you throw an Exception in your test? Do you always either 
throw just an IllegalArgumentException or a generic Exception in your 
production code?

I'm just trying to understand the forces that led to JUnit being the 
problem, rather than either an underspecified test or an oddity in the 
design, because I have learned to trust JUnit when something weird like 
this happens. I like to rule everything else out first.
